hero.subtitle: We're making conversations about relationships and reproductive health feel normal, kind, and stigma-free.

stigma.subtitle: Ever felt like it’s hard to talk about sexual health? Safhira is your space to ask, share, and be heard.

card1.title: You're Not Alone
card1.text: It’s okay to feel unsure or afraid about your sexual health—many people do. But you don’t have to face it by yourself.

card2.title: We're Here for You
card2.text: Safhira is a safe, kind, and judgment-free space where you can ask anything sexual health related and feel supported.

card3.title: Together, We Break the Silence
card3.text: When we open up, we break shame. By learning and supporting each other, we make sexual health a normal part of life.

prevalence.title: The Reality Across Malaysia
prevalence.subtitle: The lack of open conversations about sexual health has real consequences across Malaysia.

features.title: How We're Breaking Down Barriers
features.subtitle: We built a safe space where young Malaysians reach out about sexual health without fear of judgment. Here's how we support you:

final.paragraph: Sexual health shouldn't be something you figure out alone or feel ashamed about. Whether you're young or old, questioning or confident, every Malaysian deserves access to judgment-free information and support.

trust.questions: Questions welcomed, judgment left at the door

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Common sexual health questions and answers about this website.

q1.q: What are STIs and how are they transmitted?
q1.a: STIs (sexually transmitted infections) are infections that pass between people through sexual contact, including vaginal, anal, and oral sex. Some can also spread through skin-to-skin contact or sharing needles.

q2.q: Can I get an STI from oral sex?
q2.a: Yes. Infections like chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, and HPV can be transmitted through oral sex. Using protection (e.g., condoms or dental dams) reduces risk.

q3.q: Do I need testing if I have no symptoms?
q3.a: Many STIs have no symptoms. Regular testing is recommended if you are sexually active, especially with new or multiple partners. Early detection protects you and your partners.

q4.a: Many STIs are treatable and some (like chlamydia and gonorrhea) are curable with antibiotics. Others (like HIV and herpes) can be managed with treatment to stay healthy and reduce transmission.

q5.q: How can I protect myself and my partner?
q5.a: Use condoms correctly, get tested regularly, communicate openly with partners, and avoid sex when experiencing symptoms. Vaccines (e.g., HPV, hepatitis B) also help prevent some infections.

q1.q: Is my conversation private and anonymous?
q1.a: Yes. Safhira is designed to be private and anonymous. We do not store personal chat histories.

q2.a: We base our content on guidelines from trusted health organizations and review it to ensure clarity and cultural sensitivity for Malaysians.

q3.a: No. Safhira provides educational information only and cannot replace professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Please consult a healthcare professional for concerns.

q4.a: Safhira is for anyone seeking judgment-free sexual health information, especially Malaysian teens and young adults.

more.title: Still have questions?
more.subtitle: Chat with our private AI assistant.

brand.description: A safe and stigma-free learning platform for understanding reproductive health for Malaysian teens.

disclaimer.title: Important Disclaimer
disclaimer.text: Information on this website is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Please consult a doctor for proper diagnosis and treatment.

support.title: You're Taking a Positive Step
support.text: Learning about STIs shows maturity and responsibility. This information is presented without judgment, recognizing that sexual health is an important part of overall wellbeing. Remember: having an STI doesn't reflect your character—it's a health condition that can be treated or managed.

where.title: In Malaysia, you can get tested and treated at:

reminders.title: Important reminders:
items: Healthcare workers are trained to be non-judgmental
Early treatment leads to better outcomes

list.name: Chlamydia
list.description: One of the most common STIs, often without symptoms but easily treatable with antibiotics.

list.name: Gonorrhea
list.description: Bacterial infection that can affect genitals, rectum, and throat. Curable but some strains are becoming resistant.

list.name: Herpes (HSV-1 & HSV-2)
list.description: Common viral infection causing periodic outbreaks. Very manageable with modern medications.

list.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
list.description: Most common STI. Usually clears naturally, but high-risk types can cause cancer. Vaccine available.
list.prevalence: Most sexually active people get HPV

list.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
list.description: Attacks immune system but highly manageable with modern treatment. People live normal lifespans.

list.name: Syphilis
list.description: Bacterial infection that progresses through stages. Completely curable with early treatment.

Learning.prompt: Test your understanding with a quiz or ask AI if you have questions.

hero.title: STI Prevention & Safe Sex Practices
hero.subtitle: Evidence-based, culturally-sensitive information to help you make informed decisions while respecting your personal values.

methods.title: Barrier Methods (Condoms)
methods.description: Physical barriers that prevent direct contact between partners during sexual activity
methods.culturalConsiderations: Respects personal autonomy and can be used discreetly. Compatible with various cultural and religious perspectives on family planning.
howToUse: Use a new condom for each sexual encounter
Check expiration date and packaging integrity
Leave space at the tip and roll down completely
methods.evidence: WHO and CDC data consistently show high effectiveness when used correctly and consistently.

methods.title: Communication and Consent
methods.description: Open, honest dialogue about sexual health, boundaries, and testing status
methods.culturalConsiderations: Respects cultural values around communication while promoting health. Can be adapted to different cultural communication styles.
howToUse: Discuss STI testing history before intimate contact
Share personal boundaries and comfort levels
Talk about prevention methods you're both comfortable with
Check in regularly about comfort and consent
Approach conversations with respect and care
methods.evidence: Research shows couples who communicate about sexual health have lower transmission rates and higher relationship satisfaction.

methods.title: Regular Testing
methods.effectiveness: Crucial for early detection and treatment
methods.description: Routine screening for STIs based on age, risk factors, and sexual activity
methods.culturalConsiderations: Healthcare is a personal responsibility that benefits both individual and community health.
howToUse: Get tested at least annually if sexually active
Test before new relationships when possible
Follow healthcare provider recommendations for frequency
Include testing for multiple STIs, not just HIV
Share results with partners when appropriate
methods.evidence: MOH and international guidelines recommend regular screening as a cornerstone of STI prevention.

practices: Have open conversations about sexual health and boundaries
Get tested together and share results
Discuss and agree on prevention methods
Ensure both partners feel comfortable and respected
Have protection available and easily accessible
Use barrier methods consistently and correctly
Respect established boundaries and check in with your partner
Avoid practices that increase risk of tissue damage
Use appropriate lubrication to prevent tears
Switch to fresh barriers when changing activities
Maintain open communication about comfort and health
Seek medical attention if concerns arise

tips: Approach the topic when you're both relaxed
Use 'I' statements to express your feelings
Be honest about your own health and testing history
Listen actively and respect your partner's responses

samples.example: I care about both our health. When was your last STI test? I had mine [timeframe] and everything was clear.
I'd feel more comfortable using protection. How do you feel about that?
I'm comfortable with [specific activities] but would prefer to wait on [other activities]. What are your thoughts?

styles: Others value very direct, explicit discussions
Non-verbal cues may be equally important
Time and patience may be needed for comfort
navigate: Find common ground in health and care

cultural.title: Respectful & Inclusive Approach
cultural.text: This information is presented with respect for diverse cultural backgrounds, religious beliefs, and personal values. Sexual health decisions are deeply personal, and everyone deserves access to accurate information without judgment. You can adapt these practices to align with your values and circumstances.

adapt.title: Adapting to Your Circumstances
adapt.text: These practices can be adapted to fit your cultural background, relationship style, and personal comfort level. The key principles—communication, respect, and protection—remain consistent while allowing for personal and cultural variations in implementation.

clinics.title: Government Health Clinics
clinics.desc: Free or low-cost STI testing and treatment available at all government health clinics nationwide. Services are confidential and professional.
